items.question: The two most important factors that account for changes in the student's behavior are
Maturation connotes a process of
Development indicates
It refers to the progressive series of changes of an orderly and coherent type leading to the individual's maturation.

Educators are aware that no amount of practice and instruction can make a four-month old infant walk and talk because the muscular and neutral structures are not yet ready for those skills. This point to the process called ___.
The term which essentially refers to quantitative changes in the individual as he progresses in chronological age is
A coordinated set of muscular actions that are guided by conscious mental activitiy and use in performing a task is called
The head-to-foot direction in body movement is
The skills which are universally true of human race regardless of culture, sex, family background, etc. is called
A child using his arms and chest for catching a ball before he could use his hands and fingers demonstrates
Zeny is wondering why at age 14 she has not menstruated yet while her friend Remy experience menarche at age 12. Which of the following principle is applied in this situation?
Below are principles of development. Which one is questionable?

choices.text: The sequence of development is the same for all children
Certain reflexes present at birth anticipate involuntary movement

items.question: The second principle of development states that the rate of development is unique to each individual. Educators aptly termed this as the principle of ______
On what does the child's physical development depend?

choices.text: Upon environment and heredity in almost equal proportion
Primarily by inheritance modified by the environment
Upon environment fashioned depending upon the individual

items.question: Which of the following principles of human growth refers to the situation that girls mature earlier than boys?

choices.text: Each stage of development has characteristic traits
Maturation should precede certain types of learning

items.question: Maturation precedes learning. How is this applied in the classroom?

choices.text: Follow the interest in assigning tasks
Concepts should be taught from simple to complex
Give the same task to all students in a particular level
Consider the age of the students in teaching certain concepts

items.question: Infants first crawl, then stand then walk. Children draw circles before square. What development pattern is applied?

This development is most rapid in infancy but continuous quite rapidly through  the preschool years. It continuous to develop during the primary years but the rate is not as rapid as it is with the younger years.
As the children grow, they develop a greater ability to coordinate and control movement and to manipulate small objects. These are called
Which developmental stage is sometimes called the pre-school years?
The most helpless stage of human development is
The most teachable period of development
In the pre-school class of Mrs. Dela Cruz, she requires her pupils to use big pencils and crayons. She discourages the use of small pencils and crayons. What does this practice imply?

choices.text: Big pencils make big prints and make beautiful writing.
Small pencils and crayons make small prints which are difficult to read
Big pencils and crayons are easy to hold because fine motor skills are just developing
Small pencils, because they are thin, have pointed writing ends, might be dangerous to very young children

items.question: Commonality among all children which serves as a means of learning about and making sense of the world.
A teacher who realizes the educational value of the practice of providing ample opportunities for play in the curriculum would emphasize that

choices.text: students need time to play in order to develop cognitively
play is crucial to all phases of children's development: affective, motor, and cognitive
play makes learning a pleasure experience
play facilitates physical development of students

items.question: Kindergarten and elementary grade pupils are often engaged in various games as their learning activities. What principle is best observed in the situation?

choices.text: Teachers need to relax while the children are at play
Children need games to relax and enjoy
Games as a formalized expression of play are natural
Games provide wide range of social and cognitive experience

items.question: Lorraine works diligently at building a sand mountain, not looking at or speaking with the other children who are involved in other activities around her. This is an example of _____
In line with the principle of readiness, how can Ms. Shirley help her pre-schoolers to read?

choices.text: advice them to go to the library
ask them to watch educational programs

items.question: It is not wise to laugh at a two-year child when he utters bad words because in his stage he is learning to ______
Nicole, a four year old shild, does not like to attend school but her parents force her to. What principle should the teachers bear in mind in dealing with Nicole?
Between the ages of 2 and 4, the children's attention is directed to the anal region. This stage refers to the pleasure children recieve by the
Children in the kindergarten have very short attention span. What does this statement implies?

choices.text: One type of activity should be provided
Pupils should be allowed to do what they like

items.question: Abigail is praised by her parents every time she keeos her toys after playing with them. Which behavior is likely to occur by the time she enters school for the first time?

choices.text: She will teach her classmates to keep their toys after playing with them.
She can take care of her personal things she brings to school.
She might become careless with her things if not reminded by her teacher.
She will be in trouble with her classmates who don't know how to care for their toys.

items.question: What primary benefits does a child gain by participating in playgroups?

choices.text: He develops his motor and physical skills
He can practice how to relax in the midst of physical activities
He can learn and gain practice in adjusting to social demands
He can evaluate his skills in comparison to others

items.question: Which characteristics of a Grade VI pupil makes you conclude he is behind in his development in comparison with the average Grade VI pupil?

choices.text: Has not learned to get along with his agemates
Has not achieved emotional independence from his parents
Has not achieved a feminine and masculine social role
Has not achieved socially responsible behavior

items.question: Which of the following developmental tasks is not expected from a 6-12 years old child?

choices.text: Learning to get along with agemates
Learning physical skills necessary for ordinary games
Learning to control the elimination of body wastes

items.question: All of the following describe the development of children age 11 to 13 EXCEPT:

choices.text: Sex differences in IQ becomes more evident
They shift from impulsivity to adaptive ability
They exhibit increased objectivity in thinking
They show abstract thinking and judgment

items.question: When teachers understand the psychosocial development of students 6 to 12 years old they can provide

choices.text: Play activities to foster social development

items.question: Which secondary sex characteristic appears in females but not in males at the time of puberty?

choices.text: Replacement of fat with muscle tissues

items.question: Transition age from childhood to adulthood where rapid physical changes and sex maturity occur resulting in changes in ways of feelings, thinking, and acting
Which may help an adolescent discover his identity?

choices.text: Decision to follow one path only
Parents relating in to follow a specific path
Exploring many different roles in a healthy manner

items.question: Which of the following statements best describes sex differences among adolescents?

choices.text: Girls experience puberty growth later than boys
Boys and girls have the same rate of puberty growth

items.question: Which holds true of adolescence?

choices.text: Spurt in physical growth and hormonal changes

items.question: Which developmental tasks are expected of the adolescent according to Havighurst?

choices.text: Achieving new and more mature relations with the age-mates of both sexes
Learning to get along with age mates

items.question: The teacher who understands the adolescent's needs to conform will

choices.text: Use sarcasm as a disciplinary device
Disregard unique responses in discussions and on examinations
Establish a learning climate that fosters feelings of security
Lecture students on their weaknesses of character

items.question: Which of the following would you do as a teacher of adolescents?

choices.text: Activities given should be from general to specific
Always consider friendships as the basis for grouping students
Tasks to be assigned should be those that will make them feel like adults
Provide activities that will help them define their roles

items.question: Children are attracted to join gangs which exert profound influence upon them because

choices.text: They involve goals and purposes very neatly related to their own goals and purposes.
The gang is a natural step among the several steps of growth
It provides them the security that they need most during that particular time in their young life
They find a pleasant release from adult domination and individual self-direction

items.question: Which of these statements BEST explain the occurence of disciplinary infractions among adolescents in the secondary schools?

choices.text: There is a widespread lack of pre-vocational meaningful study in secondary schools
Adolescents tend to resist authority; they seek the admiration of their peers.
Syllabi are teacher-imposed, rules of conduct in secondary school are unrealistic.
Adolescents undergo rapid physical growth; they are incapable of abstract thoughts.

items.question: Which of the following activities would be very interesting for homeroom guidance sessions for adolescents?
Which of the three components of personality consists of instincts?
A stage when a girl sees her mother as a rival for her father's attention although she still has a strong attachment to her mother is called
Norman is very attached to his mother and Nina to her father. In what development stage are they according to Freudian psychoanalytical theory?
If you have to develop in the children a correct sense of right and wrong, with which should you be concerned according to Freud?
Based on Freud's theory, which operates when a child strikes a playmate at the height of anger?
When a young boy experiences rivalry with his father for his mother's attention and affection, he is experiencing
The psychanalytic theory was popularized by
This part of the personality develops as the young child learns to consider the demands of reality.

Christopher kept on thumb sucking until his adolescence. his needs during the oral development were not gratified so he became fixated at this stage. Which of the following theories is generally applied to the early experiences as an explanation for adult behavior?

An emerging thrust in determining one's personality, whether pleasant or wholesomeness one's virtues, i.e, values, relationships with others, adjustments to varying situations, behavior, and motivation
Daniel Goleman talks about emotional intelligence. Which of the folowing characterize a student with a high degree of emotional in intelligence?

choices.text: Sensitive to the points of view and feelings of others
Obsessed with achieving at any cost

items.question: Which of the following is a correct statement of emotional intelligence?

choices.text: Emotional Intelligence is being nice to people
Emotional Intelligence is giving free rein to feelings
Emotional Intelligence changes less consider than IQ through life
Emotional Intelligence is feeling appropriately and effectively

items.question: Emotionally intelligent individuals are described as having specific characteristics associate with self-awareness, impulse control, persistence, self-motivation, empathy, hope, and ______
Which is/are NOT supportive of the development of creative thinking?
What does extreme authoritarianism in home reinforce in learners?

choices.text: Doing things on their own initiative

items.question: A classroom teacher who is _____ reinforces, most Filipino's authoritarian home setting.
A type of parenting style wherein parents include children in family-decision making.
Early childhood is considered as problem age. Which of the following best supports this statement?

choices.text: demands for independence which in most cases are incapable of handling successfully

items.question: In which way does heredity affect the development of the learner?

choices.text: by compensating for what the environment fails to develop
by placing limits beyond which the learner cannot develop
by blocking the influence of environment
by providing equal potential to all

items.question: A baby is placed in her playpen most of the time. As she grows older, she was able to stand as she held on the rails of the playpen. The baby showed the ability to
If a teacher wants to help his fourth graders develop social skills, one of the first points he will have to consider with regard to social learning is that

choices.text: social roles are learned only in the family
all role relationships are defined by law
motor skills are not essential to social behavior
internalized rules determine personal interaction with others

items.question: A nursery pupil was presented with 20 plastic blocks; 15 red and 5 yellow. When asked if there were red blocks than yellow blocks, the child correctly answered "red". This mental activity to focus on one feature of objects is called
Which statement does not describe Piaget's theory of cognitive development?

choices.text: Cognitive development passes through four clearly defined objectives
each stage of cognitive development has similar observable characteristics
Each stage of cognitive development has unique observable characteristics
There are qualitative changes that occur in behavior from one stage to the next

items.question: A seven-year old child begins to understand that the amount of a flat mask of clay when rolled like a ball remains the same regardless of the shape or the way it looks. The situation shows that he is able to understand the mental concept called
Which student is functioning at Piaget's concrete operational level?

choices.text: John understands laws of conservation, can classify and seriate
Jane can apply the scientific method in problem solving
Jenny has developed concerns about social issues and personal

items.question: Two sticks are aligned in front of the child. The child agrees that they are of the same length. The teacher moves the stick to the right, and then asks the child if they are equal in length. The child answers, "No, the one of the top is longer". What skills does the child lack?
Which is the best implications of Piaget's findings that children think differently at different stages?

choices.text: children must develop capabilities to master the curriculum
materials and techniques should match the children's capabilities
schooling should be delayed until children mature intellectually
there is no pattern to cognitive development

items.question: Richie is very aloof and cold in his relationships with classmates. Which basic goal must have not been attained by Richie during his developmental years, according to Erik Erikson's theory on psychosocial development?
In which order do the three important goals during childhood be attined according to Erikson?
According to Erikson, what years are critical for the development of self-confidence?
A teacher's use of rewards and punishment is not working the same way for all pupils. The reason is probably that:

choices.text: the teacher favors some students over others
teachers and pupils have different views of what is rewarding
some pupils don't really care what will happen
